div.head:
Embleme 45. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The worke is perfected by Sol and his shade.

lg.l: The Sunne noe bodyes dense can penetrate,
And soe the adverse parts a shade create:
Which, though it be of all things least sett by,
But more to th'the Sophi are the Sunne and shade,
Because they perfect the auriferous trade.

div.head: Discourse 45.
div.ab:
As in a round or SphericallSpherical Palace, a fire kindled in one place illustrates
the parts above and below round about all the walls, except those, where
a table or the like standing in the midle may by its objection and inter
position impede, and admitt a darke shadow; Soe allso the Sunne being-
placed in that great Palace or carved theater of the heaven dos by its-
rayes illuminate evry concavity of heaven, the bodyes containdcontained therein
which are diaphanous and receptive of light, that is, all starrs whatsoever
both erraticke and fixed, except where the density of the earth in the-
midle may prohibit: For there a blacke and darke shadow, which is called
night, continues soe long, till it be driven away by the præsencepresence of-
the Sunne, and light established and made conspicuous in stead thereof:
A shadow therefore and night is the privation or absence (as day on the-
contrary is the irradiation and circumfusion) of the Solar light. A shadow
is that which cannot endure the aspect of the Sunne, and therefore-
avoyds and absconds itselfe sometimes in this sometimes in that part of
the earth, as the Sunne is in opposition. The Sunne and shadow never
saw themselves together, though, if nature would admitt, they might in
every moment, but the Sunne considering her as an enemy to himselfe,
allwayes pursues her flying, and can never take her weary, as BuchananBuchanan?
in his booke of Spheres ingeniously hath declared: For imitation and-
example of that great Sunne, and shadow thereof, the Philosophers have
observed that their Sunne hath allso a blacke, cloudy, and flying Shadow:
Hereupon Sayth Hermes, My Sonne! take from the ray its shadow, that is,
see that you bring your Sunne round about the primum mobile, of-
which Vulcan is made overseer, that even that part of your Earth, which
is now covered with a shady night, may obtaine the clear light of the-
Sunne: for if the whole Firmament of the heaven with all things con
tained were not every naturall day, that is, in twenty four houres alltogether
circumvolved by the first motion, but the Sunne onely moved by its owne
(calld the second and annuallannual) motion, it would happen that they, which
are Antipodes below us, would for the Space of allmost six moneths have
a night, and wee a day, and afterwards on the contrary they a day and-
wee a night; soe that the whole year would consist of one night and-
day, as now these courses are by experience and reason confirmed to be-
most true under both the Poles: But it seemdseemed farre otherwise to divine provi
dence, which therefore hath ordained two motions of the Planets, the first
and second, and soe distributed the year into many dayes: Now that sha
dow and Sunne doe together make day and night, which the Sunne by
itselfe alone could not effect, whose property it is to illuminate all opposite
places and bodyes, but not make a shadow, except accidentally by his absence:
Soe allso the Philosophicall Sunne dos with its shadow make a day, that
is, light and night or darkenesse, namely Latona or Magnesia, whose-
Shadow Democritus teachethteaches, as appears in the third booke of his-
Discourse 45.
Golden table at the begining, must be extinguished and consumed by a fiery
medicine. The utility of shadows in Astronomicall affairs is soe great, that-
without them that Science can scarce be perfected; Chymists doe allso ascribe
it to their shadows, that their art comes to perfection; for what is this Sunne-
without a shadow? As a clapper without a bell: That indeed makes the first
motion to a sound, but this gives the sound; that is the quill, this the instru
ment; that the tongue, this the great mouth: A shadow is a most contemptible
thing, not next to a Being, soe allso the Philosophers shadow is a thing-
blacke blacker than blacke, as they termeterm it, or of lesse esteem than weeds,-
not in respect of itselfe, but the opinion of men and plenty; What more-
coḿodious than fire, what more pretious than water, what more amiable-
than earth, which yeilds flowers and all amiable things, what more plea
sant than aire, which being restraindrestrained and obstructed, all things cease to be
pleasant? Yet neverthelesse, because they are exposd to mens uses in their
large Spheres, they are esteemed most vile, by a præposterouspreposterous imagination:-
Soe allso is both the common and Philosophicall shadow undervalued; They-
that live long in subterranean shadows, if brought suddenly to the clear-
light of the Sunne, doe loose their eye-sight; Soe they that reside and
operate in the Philosophicall shadow alone, and doe not joyne the-
Sunne with it, are deprived of judgement and the sight of the mind, and
frustrated of the effect: The cælestiall Sunne being elevated upon the-
South there is greater heat and lesse shadow; soe allso here heat being in
creased the shadow is diminished, and on the contrary; Wee must there
fore begin the Sunne being from the meridionallmeridional side bending itselfe-
againe to the top of our head, in CapricorneCapricorn; and the first operation will-
be even finished at Aries, then begins the womens worke, even to Leo;-
and afterwards labour proceeds from labour, till the year take the tayle
with the head, as a Snake, that is to say, is completed. . . . . . .
